title: What explains recent tech layoffs, and why should we be worried? | Stanford News

last_post.content:
Layoffs:
- don't save money
- don't improve company performance
- don't increase stock pricess
- destroy trust
- have huge impacts on health, well-being, and income of employees

So why do layoffs? It's a network effect: execs lay people off because other companies are doing it

Stanford Biz School article: https://news.stanford.edu/2022/12/05/explains-recent-tech-layoffs-worried/

Harvard Biz Review:
https://hbr.org/2022/12/what-companies-still-get-wrong-about-layoffs
So incredibly proud to have signed onto this letter to the NYT calling out the harms of their anti-trans coverage. https://nytletter.com/

title: Journalists (And Others) Should Leave Twitter. Here’s How They Can Get Started

last_post.content:
I am NOT saying journalism should leave Twitter this minute (though that would be gratifying).

I am saying news orgs and journalists should announce their intention to do so, and move expeditiously to places like this.

See my recent TechDirt post for the why, and how: https://www.techdirt.com/2023/01/04/journalists-and-others-should-leave-twitter-heres-how-they-can-get-started/

RT @dkbrereton@twitter.com

You can read my full analysis of the mistakes in Bing's demo here: https://dkb.blog/p/bing-ai-cant-be-trusted

🐦🔗: https://twitter.com/dkbrereton/status/1625237322018000896

title: Letter: Imposing Fees to Access the Twitter API Threatens Public-Interest Research

last_post.content:
Imposing fees to access the Twitter API threatens public-interest research. At CWTS we promote open (meta)data and transparency in science generally, and we believe Twitter data should also be accessible for research purposes. We study the use of science by the broader public, for which access to Twitter data is a relevant component. We therefore decided to sign this letter, and we call on others to do the same.

https://independenttechresearch.org/letter-twitter-api-access-threatens-public-interest-research/

As always, feedback welcome! One of the benefits of the ebook format is that I can correct errors or edit to provide more context quickly.

title: Greta Thunberg says world leaders not even ‘moving in the right direction’ on climate

last_post.content:
As usual, she does not mince words...
____________________________

Swedish climate activist Greta Thunberg said in an op-ed published Monday that the world’s leaders are not even “moving in the right direction” on addressing the growing climate crisis.

Writing in the Los Angeles Times, Thunberg, 20, said that financial resources need to be aggressively poured into “solutions, adaptations, and restorations” to address climate change, but that the funds are currently “going elsewhere.”

“The often-used argument that ‘we don’t have enough money’ has been disproven so many times,” Thunberg wrote. “According to the International Monetary Fund, the production and burning of coal, oil and fossil gas was subsidized by $5.9 trillion in 2020 alone. That is $11 million every minute, earmarked for planetary destruction.”

“During the COVID-19 pandemic, governments around the world launched unprecedented financial rescue packages. These recovery plans were seen as a huge opportunity to set humanity on a brand-new course for a more sustainable economic paradigm. They were called ‘our last chance to avert a climate disaster,’ as the enormous size of the investments would make it impossible for us to undo their consequences in the future if we got that funding even slightly wrong,” she said.

But, according to the International Energy Agency, only 2 percent of those massive financial aid packages went toward green energy, Thunberg said.

“Our leaders completely failed,” she wrote.

“And they continue to fail; despite all the beautiful words and pledges, they are not moving in the right direction. In fact, we are still expanding fossil fuel infrastructure all over the world. In many cases, we are even speeding up the process. China is planning to build 43 new coal power plants on top of the 1,000 plants already in operation. In the U.S., approvals for companies to drill for oil and fossil methane gas are on schedule to reach their highest level since the presidency of George W. Bush,” she wrote.

FULL ARTICLE -- https://thehill.com/policy/energy-environment/3856605-greta-thunberg-says-world-leaders-not-even-moving-in-the-right-direction-on-climate/

#GreenWashing #ClimateCrisis #KeepItInTheGround #GretaThunberg

While researching my recent newsletter post about radio frequency allocations, I stumbled upon this lil gem. NOAA runs a "Dial-A-Buoy" service where you can...dial a buoy. Call 888-701-8992. Once connected, press 1 then then buoy ID number. You can try it out for buoy 44065 in New York Harbor. https://www.ndbc.noaa.gov/dial.shtml#:~:text=Some%20buoys%20report%20wave%20directions,touch%20tone%20or%20cell%20phone.

title: Dorothea Lange’s Censored Photographs of FDR’s Japanese Concentration Camps — Anchor Editions

last_post.content:
We all have different things that touch us. For some, it's stories on the printed page. For others, songs or spoken narratives. For yet others, photographs.

You may not know that the US government hired Dorothea Lange to photograph the "relocation effort."

She clearly saw the injustice and human tragedy that was unfolding, and documented it unflinchingly.

Her work was censored, and only in 2006 made broadly available.

Take a moment and see what she saw.

https://anchoreditions.com/blog/dorothea-lange-censored-photographs

title: Opinion | A Nationwide Ban on TikTok Won’t Make Us More Secure

last_post.content:
Let's say the Chinese government was using TikTok to surveil Americans.

If you ban Tik Tok, the Chinese gov can just legally purchase the same info from data brokers, because the US has almost no privacy laws.

Don't ban TikTok, pass a damn privacy law https://www.nytimes.com/2023/02/01/opinion/tiktok-ban-china.html

title: Decision diagrams in operations research, optimization, vehicle routing, and beyond

last_post.content:
A MIP solver, CP solver, and decision diagram solver walk into a bar.

The MIP solver says, “Give me your best beer, I’ll wait.”

The CP solver says, “Give me any drink, just as long as it’s a drink.”

The DD solver says, “I’ll have my beer and drink it too.”

Join Ryan on Thursday in raising a glass to decision diagrams in optimization: https://www.nextmv.io/videos/decision-diagrams-in-operations-research-optimization-vehicle-routing-and-beyond

#orms #decisiondiagrams #mixedintegerprogramming

title: Der Matilda-Effekt: Wie Frauen in der Wissenschaft unsichtbar werden

last_post.content:
1945 erhielt Otto Hahn für die Entdeckung der Kernspaltung den Nobelpreis. Seine langjährige Kollegin Lise Meitner ging leer aus – und das, obwohl ihr Wissen und ihre Arbeit unabdingbar für die preisgekrönte Entdeckung waren.

Mit dieser Auslassung ist Lise Meitner nicht alleine. Zahlreiche Wissenschaftlerinnen erlitten im Laufe der Geschichte das gleiche Schicksal: Ihre Errungenschaften wurden in der Wissenschaftsgeschichte vergessen, ausgeklammert oder ignoriert.

https://www.nationalgeographic.de/geschichte-und-kultur/2023/02/diskriminierung-der-matilda-effekt-wie-frauen-in-der-wissenschaft-unsichtbar-werden

title: Latest attack on PyPI users shows crooks are only getting better

last_post.content:
#Python users: beware that the use of PyPI as an attack vector continues and the perpetrators are trying new methods. Targeted packages include Pandas, Beautiful Soup, PyInstaller, Scrapy, TensorFlow, PyTorch, and others.
https://arstechnica.com/information-technology/2023/02/451-malicious-packages-available-in-pypi-contained-crypto-stealing-malware/?utm_brand=arstechnica

title: A Secret for Falling Asleep So Good It’s a British National Treasure

last_post.content:
“Vastness, as such, is appealing, and the world is so very vast. Long-wave broadcasts travel far, hugging the planet as they make their way overseas. Like the sea itself, the Shipping Forecast is a reminder of the larger, more elemental forces at play, those things that are much more powerful than any of our individual worries or wants.”

https://www.nytimes.com/2023/02/14/magazine/falling-asleep-shipping-forecast.html

I love space photos and have for some time wanted to code a generative art system to capture the grandiosity and awe of images such as seen in @hourlycosmos.

Then, this week I discovered that @tylermorganwall has a tutorial for rayrendering Saturn and its rings.

Raiding his code led to a system to simulate planets and their rings. I call it _Ideal Astronomies_.

Done in #Rstats using #rayrender; see my repo:

https://github.com/paezha/ideal-astronomies

#Rtistry #CreativeCoding

@meghansharris @jacquietran

title: Artificial neural networks today are not conscious, according to Douglas Hofstadter

last_post.content:
Douglas Hofstadter writes, "I would call GPT-3’s answers not just clueless but cluelessly clueless, meaning that GPT-3 has no idea that it has no idea about what it is saying ... The system just starts babbling randomly—but it has no sense that its random babbling is random babbling."
https://www.economist.com/by-invitation/2022/06/09/artificial-neural-networks-today-are-not-conscious-according-to-douglas-hofstadter

If you've been ignoring your deprecation warnings then pandas 2.0.0 will break your code

If you've been paying attention to your deprecation warnings then pandas 2.0.0 might still break your code, but probably far less

The safest thing you can do is to try out the nightly releases, which you can easily `pip install`, see https://pandas.pydata.org/docs/dev/getting_started/install.html#installing-the-development-version-of-pandas

In-progress release notes: https://pandas.pydata.org/docs/dev/whatsnew/v2.0.0.html

title: Blue Alchemist Technology Powers our Lunar Future | Blue Origin

last_post.content: Blue Origin says they can make solar cells and wire from simulated lunar regolith (the rocks and dust on the Moon's surface). "Oxygen for propulsion and life support is a byproduct." https://www.blueorigin.com/news/blue-alchemist-powers-our-lunar-future/

title: When you're a manager, your behavior is under a microscope - Jacob Kaplan-Moss

last_post.content:
Hey managers, please don't ask for "mystery meat" conversations with your directs -- i.e., no "hey do you have a minute?" DMs, or surprise calendar invites with vague titles. Always include the topic: "hey, can we talk about client X? I need some information about the meeting last week".

Otherwise, many (most?) of your directs will immediately assume the worst: "hey, do you have a minute ... so I can fire you?" "Hey, can we talk ... about what a failure you are?"

More: https://jacobian.org/2021/oct/26/manager-microscope/

title: Let’s Stop Pretending Clarence Thomas Can Read the Framers’ Minds

last_post.content:
Now out, a piece co-written with @Dahlialith, and given a terrific headline by Jeremy Stahl: “Let’s Stop Pretending Clarence Thomas Can Read the Framers’ Minds."

We explain that *nothing* about historical analogy requires the Supreme Court to allow domestic abusers, among others, to have guns.

https://slate.com/news-and-politics/2023/02/gun-laws-bruen-clarence-thomas-framers-domestic-abuse.html

Disheartened by the monetization of *everything*, and by the attacks on public things (à la @BonnieHonig) like libraries + schools, I wondered what we can learn from one of my favorite public things: drinking fountains. So, I wrote about them for Places Journal!

https://placesjournal.org/article/drinking-fountains-and-public-goods/
